author: Aidan Flynn
bio: Aidan Flynn is a Teaching Fellow in the Department of Architecture at MIT. He holds a B.A. (hons.) from the University of Toronto, where he double majored in Art History and Renaissance Studies; and a Master of Science in Architecture Studies (S.M.Arch.S.) in the History, Theory + Criticism of Architecture and Art from MIT. Aidan has taught classes on queer theory, design, and advanced writing for architecture. Aidan is the Co-Principal Investigator for the inaugural Queer Space Lab at MIT, wherein he teaches and works with a team of students and scholars as they seek out new methodologies in the study and practice of architecture. Aidan’s research is concerned with the complex relationships between gender, sexuality, and space in the early modern and modern worlds.

author: Okki Berendschot
bio:
Okki Berendschot is a designer and writer based in Brooklyn. Her work focuses on the potential of storytelling and participatory design to help facilitate a deeper understanding of the complex and unjust forces that shape cities. Most recently, she is creating a graphic novel about the lived experiences of displaced communities due to urban renewal in downtown Brooklyn, as a counternarrative to the historical accounts found in archives. 

She received a Master of City Planning from MIT’s School of Architecture and Planning where she was awarded the Hebbert Student Contribution Award, and a B.Arch from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute where she was the recipient of the Peck Thesis Prize. Her research has led her to collaborate with the Leventhal Map and Education Center as a research fellow and the Civic Data Design Lab as a graduate research assistant. She has industry experience working as an licensed architect in the offices of SAA/Stan Allen Architecture, Steven Holl Architects, Levenbetts Architects, Fogarty Finger Architects and KPFui. Her teams’ work has been exhibited in the Venice Biennale, GA Gallery, Art OMI, and others.

author: Doris Duanmu
bio: Doris is an architectural and urban designer originally from Guangzhou, China. She received a B.Arch degree from the University of Southern California and worked as a designer specializing in sports and entertainment venue design before joining MIT. Doris is currently pursuing her master's degree in Urbanism (SMArchS). Her research interests fall in spatial, social, and political discussion on the urban scape, especially on civic participation, gender, and sexuality. She is keen on utilizing design thinking to guide the research, integrating writing, drawing, and curating methods into the process.

author: Felix Li
bio: Felix Li is currently studying Art and Design, and Comparative Media Studies at MIT.

author: Merve Akdogan
bio: An interdisciplinary designer and architect, Merve Akdogan works in the areas of computational design, visualization, architectural design, public art, exhibition design and so on. They assess the ideas they deal with in their personal art practice and works in the context of body-space relationship based on cultural diversity, queer theories, bodily existence, bodily modifications, and their relationships with spatial aspects. In addition to their professional practices in architecture and design. They continued to work as tattoo artists in this setting, and more recently, their research interests have shifted to on-skin and wearable technologies. Human-self, human-community, human-biological organisms, human-body, body-physical space, body-virtual space, interactive extensions, wearable technologies, ecological thinking, cyborg manifestos, and queer spaces are among the subjects and relationships they discuss. They place a strong emphasis on regenerative responses to societal and cultural variations.

author: Tj Bayowa
bio: Tj is a student pursuing a master degree in architecture at MIT.

author: Mingjia Chen
bio: Mingjia Chen is a graduate student currently completing their Master of Architecture at the MIT Department of Architecture.

author: Caroline Chea
bio: Caroline Chea is a rising sophomore at MIT, majoring in course 11-6 (Urban Science and Planning with Computer Science). She is interested in how the structure of spaces shapes individual and community experiences. In the Queer Space Lab, Caroline is especially curious about exploring how different online platforms shape the queer (especially asexual) individual and community experiences. Additionally, Caroline dedicates time to building and maintaining personal and institutional archives. She has studied bookbinding technologies and archival practices in the Wunsch Conservation Lab.

author: Nina (Yihong) Li
bio: Nina (Yihong) Li is a class of 2024 undergrad student double majoring in architecture and literature. She grew up in Qingdao, China and moved to New Jersey when she was 12 years old. She is intrigued by visual art, history, aesthetics, existential philosophy, or any mixture of those. She has a background in 2D art-making and has a wide range of interest from exploring interactive spatial designs to appreciating fat, furry cats.
